ON AFFINE SELECTIONS OF SET–VALUED FUNCTIONS

arXiv:0807.4157v1 [math.FA] 25 Jul 2008

SZYMON WASOWICZ
 ̨
A BSTRACT. The main result of this paper is the theorem stating that every convex set–
valued function F : I 7→ c(Y ), where I ⊂ R is an interval and Y is locally convex space,
possesses an affine selection. In the case if Y = R and the values of F are closed real
intervals we can replace the assumption of convexity of F by the more general condition.

1. I NTRODUCTION
K. Nikodem and Sz. Wasowicz
 ̨
have proved (cf. [4, theorem 1]) that if the functions
f, g : I 7→ R, where I ⊂ R is an interval, fulfil for every x, y ∈ I, t ∈ [0, 1] the following
condition

f tx + (1 − t)y ≤ tg(x) + (1 − t)g(y),

g tx + (1 − t)y ≥ tf (x) + (1 − t)f (y),
then there exists an affine function h : I → R such that f ≤ h ≤ g on I. The simple
consequence of this fact is Theorem 1 which we prove at the beginning of this paper. Next
we prove that every convex set–valued function F : I → c(Y ), where Y is a locally convex
space and c(Y ) is the family of all compact non–empty subsets of Y , possesses an affine
selection. In the case Y = Rn , n ∈ N, we also present a direct inductive proof of this
theorem.
Notation. By I we will denote any fixed real interval. If X is a topological vector space
then we admit the following notation:
n(X) = { A ⊂ X : A 6= ∅ }
c(X) = { A ∈ n(X) : A is a compact set }
cc(X) = { A ∈ c(X) : A is a convex set }.
The term set–valued function will be abbreviated in the form s.v. function.
If X, Y are vector spaces and D ⊂ X is a convex set then we say that a s.v. function
F : D → n(Y ) is
(a) convex, if for every x, y ∈ D, t ∈ [0, 1]

tF (x) + (1 − t)F (y) ⊂ F tx + (1 − t)y ;
(b) concave, if for every x, y ∈ D, t ∈ [0, 1]

F tx + (1 − t)y ⊂ tF (x) + (1 − t)F (y).

A function f : D → Y is called the selection of the s.v. function F : D → n(Y ) iff
f (x) ∈ F (x) for every x ∈ D.

1991 Mathematics Subject Classification. Primary: 26E25; Secondary: 54C65.
Key words and phrases. Set–valued functions, selections, convex (concave) set–valued functions, affine functions, locally convex spaces.

2. R ESULTS
Let us start with the translation of the theorem mentioned in the Introduction into the s.v.
functions language (cf. [1, Remark 14]).
Theorem 1. A s.v. function F : I → cc(R) possesses an affine selection iff for every
x, y ∈ I, t ∈ [0, 1] the following condition holds

(1)
F tx + (1 − t)y ∩ [tF (x) + (1 − t)F (y)] 6= ∅.
Before we start the proof let us observe that (1) is the weakest condition guaranteeing
the existence of an affine selection for the s.v. function F .
Proof of Theorem 1. If there exists an affine selection f : I → R of the s.v. function F
then the condition (1) is obvious.
Let us assume that the condition (1) holds for every x, y ∈ I, t ∈ [0, 1]. Let

Remark 2. It is well known that if a s.v. function F : I → cc(R) is convex (or concave)
then F has an affine selection. Applying the above theorem we get the new proof of this
fact.
Remark 3. The assumption of compactness of the sets F (x), x ∈ I in Theorem 1 is
essential. Consider two s.v. functions F : R → n(R) and G : (−1, 1) → n(R) defined by
the formulas
F (x) = [x2 , +∞),

x ∈ (−1, 1).

It is easy to see that F and G are convex, but they do not have any affine selection.
Remark 4. It is known (cf. [2, Remark 1], [4, Remark 2]) that a s.v. function F : D →
cc(R), where D ⊂ R2 is a convex set, need not possess any affine selection although F
fulfils (1). We can also find the example of the s.v. function F : I → cc(R2 ) which
fulfils (1) and does not have any affine selection. So, Theorem 1 can not be generalized
both for s.v. functions defined on the convex subset of the plane and for s.v. functions
F : I → cc(R2 ). Below we present an example which is due to E. Sadowska from
Bielsko–Biała.

 ON AFFINE SELECTIONS OF SET–VALUED FUNCTIONS

Let I = [0, 4] (only in this remark) and F : I → cc(R2 ) be defined as follows
F (0) = [−4, 4] × {1},
F (1) = {−1} × [−4, 4],
F (2) = [−4, 4] × {−1},
F (3) = {1} × [−4, 4],
F (4) = { (x, x) : x ∈ [−4, 4] },
F (x) = [−4, 4] × [−4, 4] for all x ∈ I \ {0, 1, 2, 3, 4}.
One can prove that F fulfils (1). We will show that F does not possess any affine selection.

It is well known that every continuous function f : I → I has a fixed point (if I is the
closed interval). On the second hand, every affine function f : I → I is continuous. So, as
a consequence of Theorem 1 we obtain the following
Corollary 5. If the interval I is closed then every s.v. function F : I → cc(I) fulfilling (1)
has a fixed point (i.e. there exists a point x ∈ I such that x ∈ F (x)).
Now we shall prove the main theorem of this paper. We present two proofs. One of them
is an application of K. Nikodem's results (cf. [2]) and it requires the Axiom of Choice. The
second one is direct and inductive but it works for finite–dimensional spaces Rn .
Theorem 6. Let Y be a locally convex topological vector space. Every convex s.v. function
F : I → c(Y ) possesses an affine selection f : I → Y .
Proof. Let F : I → c(Y ) be a convex s.v. function. Then, in particular, F is a midconvex s.v. function (it fulfils the condition of convexity with t = 1/2), and so F possesses

Since F is continuous on Int I as a convex s.v. function defined on a subset of R (cf.
[3, Theorem 3.7]), also f is continuous (cf. [3, Theorem 4.3] with K = {0}, G = F and
F = f ). Thus f as a continuous Jensen function is an affine function, which completes the
proof.

In the above proof we have used K. Nikodem's results which require the Lemma of
Kuratowski–Zorn and some versions of the Theorem of Hahn–Banach. Below we give an
inductive proof in the case Y = Rn , n ∈ N.
Second proof (for Y = Rn ). Before we start an induction on n let us notice that if F is
convex then the values of F are convex sets.
If n = 1 then our theorem follows directly from Remark 2. Assume that every convex
s.v. function G : I → c(Rn ) has an affine selection g : I → Rn . Let F : I → c(Rn+1 ) be
a convex s.v. function. For any x ∈ I we put

We will check that G is a convex s.v. function. Fix any x1 , x2 ∈ I, t ∈ [0, 1]. Let

So there exist zi ∈ R, i = 1, 2, such that (yi , zi ) ∈ F (xi ), i = 1, 2. Let z = tz1 +(1−t)z2 .
Since F is convex we get

Let g : I → Rn be an affine selection of G. Let us define

Obviously, H(x) is a compact and convex subset of R. From the fact that g(x) ∈ G(x)
we get that H(x) 6= ∅, x ∈ I. So H : I → cc(R). It is not difficult to check that H is a
convex s.v. function.

Let h : I → R be an affine selection of H. By putting f (x) := g(x), h(x) , x ∈ I, we
obtain an affine selection of the s.v. function F , which completes the proof.

Remark 7. The above proof was obtained as a result of investigations if s.v. functions
F : I → cc(Rn ) fulfilling the condition (1) possess an affine selection. First the author
hoped that the method of decreasing of the dimension will give an effect in this case. But
the example in Remark 4 gave the negative answer of the mentioned problem. However in
the case of convex s.v. functions this direct method gives the simple way of constructing
the affine selections.
Remark 8. It is known that convex s.v. functions F : D → cc(R), where D is a convex
subset of Rn , n ≥ 2, need not possess any affine selection (cf. [2, Remark 1]). However, if
D is a convex cone with base in a real linear space, then every convex s.v. function defined
on D with compact values in a real locally convex space has an affine selection. It was
obtained recently by A. Smajdor and W. Smajdor [5].
Remark 9. It is known that the convex s.v. function F : I → c(Y ), where Y is a topological vector space are continuous. An application of our results gives another proof of this
fact in the case when Y = Rn . Using Theorem 6 (for Y = Rn ) we obtain the existence of
an affine selection f of F . Since f is affine and f : I → Rn , it must be continuous. Then
F has a continuous selection, so F must be continuous on I (cf. [3, Theorem 3.3]).
